page.title: 02Landscape, geology & relief
page.content:
This is an area of low hills and small streams. The underlying rocks are mostly clays of Jurassic age, incorporating varying amounts of broken limestone. The higher ground, running from north-east to south-west across the block, is of a limy clay called Forest Marble, while in the more low-lying parts the clay is often covered by alluvium or head. There are no rocky outcrops. In the extreme north and east of the block there are some patches of the nodular limestone known as cornbrash, and this is where the best arable land is found.
The highest point in the block is in Pen Wood at about 170m. Abbots Hill rises to 139m, the Closworth ridge in the east to 117m. Sutton Bingham reservoir is at about 60m, and Halstock Church at 64m.
